scenario:
Azlin, 38, is a newly-minted equity partner specialising in commercial law at a mid-sized
Singapore law ﬁrm. Her husband Kok Tong, also 38, does investments and trading at a
local bank. The two had recently gotten married in Jan 2020.
On 1 Feb 2020, they moved into a 3 storey landed bungalow they had bought in the Katong
area. The house is one of those nice heritage houses with a long colonial history. It is part
of a cluster of houses designed and built in 1940 by Due South Ltd, now a big listed
Singapore property developer. After the cluster was built, title of the common areas was
vested in the estate’s MCST. Azlin and Kok Tong (henceforth “A&K”) are the third owners
of the house. They ofﬁcially took over ownership on 31 Oct 2019.
Before moving in, they engaged Disastrous Interiors Pte Ltd (“DI”), an interior design
and furniture company, to plan and also implement a series of renovations. This included
building a new wall fountain in their living room (the sort where water ﬂows down along
a feature wall and into a pool). To preserve the heritage feel of the house, A&K asked that
DI construct the fountain on an existing 3-metre long stretch of heritage wall that lined
their living room. DI inserts some water pipes and pumps in the wall to make this happen.
They also add some claddings to the heritage wall. The $300,000 contract between A&K
and DI does not contain any relevant exclusion clause.
A&K’s discussions with DI took place over Nov 2019. From 1 Dec 2019 to 31 Jan 2020,
DI cordoned off the house as a construction site, putting up the usual barriers and warnings,
and carried out the renovations. From time to time DI would invite A&K over to have a
look at the progress, and A&K would give some creative direction and feedback.
Unfortunately for the newlyweds, their new life together was fraught with twists and turns.
Within a month of moving in, they received a lawyer’s letter from one Tom, a 24 year old
photographer who specialises in taking pictures for interior design magazines. On 15 Jan
2020, Tom had passed by the house on his way to a photoshoot. From outside, Tom could
see from over the 1.5m tall construction site fence that a beautifully renovated colonial
house stood behind it. He thus climbed over the fence hoping to take a few pictures. Tom

did not however notice a long electrical wire that was carelessly strewn across the ﬂoor.
He tripped, dropping and breaking his $2,500 camera. Because his camera was broken,
he also had to miss the photoshoot he was heading to that day, making for lost proﬁts of a
further $10,000. He is now demanding compensation for both from A&K only.
In Feb 2020, parts of the wall fountain started breaking off and falling into the pool below.
It turned out that DI completely miscalculated how much weight the wall would be able
to bear. Due South had built the wall exactly to 1940 standards (which were signiﬁcantly
lower than today’s). A&K will need to pay $200,000 to re-do the entire wall and wall
fountain. They are hoping to claim compensation for this from either Due South or DI or
both.
Finally, within days of moving in, the couple starting hearing strange noises and having
strange sightings in the house. They had heard from the previous owners a folk tale that
the house was previously used as a holding area for prisoners during the Sook Ching
massacre.1 They would catch momentary glimpses of what seemed like a phantom dressed
like the Japanese military police patrolling their corridors. Once the phantom even shouted
Azlin’s name. Kok Tong is a serious history buff who knows about the atrocities committed
during the time. He is very afraid and has many sleepless nights. Eventually he develops
severe paranoia, a recognised psychiatric injury.
Azlin, who witnesses her husband slowly falling into paranoia, is extremely distressed as
well. She takes it upon herself to confront the phantom. Having practiced law for so many
years, she had developed nerves of steel. One night, as the phantom emerged, she lunges
at it without thinking. To her utmost surprise, she did not pass right through the phantom.
Instead, both of them fell to the ground. “Ouch! That hurt!”, belches the ‘phantom’. It was
actually Hartono, Azlin’s jilted ex-boyfriend, who had been jealous of the newlyweds. He
had spent the last month sneaking into their home trying sabotage their relationship. He
especially wanted to scare Azlin into leaving Kok Tong.
1This was a period during the Japanese Occupation (1942–1945) where thousands of Singaporeans were
murdered by the Japanese military.
questions:
1. Does Tom have any tort claim(s) against A&K? If not, who if anyone should they
ask Tom to go after and why?

2. Leaving aside any limitation issues, do A&K have any tort claim(s) against Due
South or DI in relation to the wall?
3. Do A&K have any intentional tort claim(s) against Hartono?
4. Are there any other tort-related issues that A&K should know about?

**Issue**: Did A&K owe a duty of care to Tom?

**Rule**: Under Singapore law, a duty of care arises when the defendant has created a state of affairs which he knows or ought to have known would, if not controlled, cause damage to the plaintiff. (Caparo Industries plc v Dickman [1990] 2 AC 605)

**Application**: In this scenario, A&K engaged DI to carry out renovations on their house, which included building a wall fountain. They knew or ought to have known that the construction site would attract visitors, as Tom was passing by and decided to take pictures. They had a duty to take reasonable care to prevent harm to visitors. However, they failed to ensure that the construction site was safe, as evidenced by the electrical wire strewn across the floor. This breach of duty caused Tom's camera to be broken and him to miss a photoshoot.

**Conclusion**: Therefore, A&K did owe a duty of care to Tom and breached that duty, making them liable for Tom's damages.

**Issue**: Can A&K claim against DI for the damages caused by the wall fountain?

**Rule**: Under the Contracts (Rights of Third Parties) Act (Cap 53B), a third party can enforce a term of a contract if the contract expressly provides for this, or if it is reasonable to infer from the contract that the parties intended to confer a benefit on the third party.

**Application**: The contract between A&K and DI does not contain any relevant exclusion clause, and it is reasonable to infer that A&K intended to confer a benefit on themselves as the owners of the house. Therefore, A&K can claim against DI for the damages caused by the wall fountain.

**Issue**: Can Kok Tong claim against Due South for his psychiatric injury?

**Rule**: Under the Occupiers' Liability Act (Cap 222), an occupier of premises owes a duty to visitors to take such care as is reasonable in all the circumstances to see that the visitor will be reasonably safe in using the premises for the purpose for which he is invited or permitted by the occupier to be there.

**Application**: Due South is the occupier of the common areas of the estate, and Kok Tong is a visitor to those areas. However, Kok Tong's psychiatric injury was not caused by any defect in the common areas, but rather by the presence of Hartono in the house. Therefore, Due South does not owe a duty of care to Kok Tong in this regard.

**Conclusion**: Kok Tong cannot claim

My answer is:
**Issue**: Can A&K sue Due South or DI for the damages caused by the wall fountain?

**Rule**:
- **Negligence**: A duty of care is owed by a defendant to a claimant if it is reasonably foreseeable that the claimant would suffer injury as a result of the defendant's negligent act or omission (Caparo Industries plc v Dickman [1990] 2 AC 605).
- **Defective Premises**: A landlord or builder owes a duty of care to ensure that the premises are safe and fit for habitation (National Car Rental System Inc v McCain [1989] 1 WLR 297).
- **Economic Loss**: Pure economic loss is not recoverable in negligence unless there is a special relationship between the parties (Spartan Steel & Alloys Ltd v Martin & Co (Contractors) Ltd [1973] QB 27).

**Application**:
- **Due South**: As the original builder of the house, Due South had a duty of care to ensure that the house was safe and fit for habitation. However, this duty would have been discharged once they transferred the title to the first owners. Therefore, A&K cannot sue Due South for the damages caused by the wall fountain.
- **DI**: DI had a duty of care to A&K as they were engaged to carry out renovations on the house. They breached this duty by miscalculating the weight the wall could bear, leading to the wall fountain collapsing. A&K can sue DI for the damages caused by the wall fountain.

**Conclusion**: A&K can only sue DI for the damages caused by the wall fountain, as Due South's duty of care would have been discharged upon transferring the title to the first owners.

My answer is:
**Issue**: Can A&K bring an intentional tort claim against Hartono?

**Rule**:
- **Battery**: An intentional tort where the defendant intentionally makes physical contact with the plaintiff without their consent. (See *Collins v Wilcock* [1984] 3 All ER 374)
- **Criminal Trespass**: An offence under the Penal Code (Cap 224) where a person enters any building with the intention to commit an offence or to intimidate, insult, or annoy any person in or in the vicinity of that building.

**Application**:
- Hartono intentionally entered A&K's house without their consent, which constitutes criminal trespass.
- Hartono's actions of sneaking into their home, making strange noises, and dressing up as a Japanese military police to scare them also amount to battery, as he intentionally made physical contact with Azlin without her consent.

**Conclusion**: Therefore, A&K can bring intentional tort claims of battery and criminal trespass against Hartono.

**Rule**: Under Singapore law, a claim in negligence requires the plaintiff to establish that the defendant owed them a duty of care, breached that duty, and caused damage as a result. In the context of property defects, the occupier's liability provisions in the Building Maintenance and Strata Management Act (BMSMA) may apply. Section 10(1) of the BMSMA imposes a duty on the developer to ensure that the building is fit for habitation and occupation. However, this duty is subject to a limitation period of six years from the date of completion of the building (Section 10(3) BMSMA).

**Application**: In this scenario, Due South built the house in 1940, and A&K purchased it in 2019. The wall was constructed to 1940 standards, which were significantly lower than today's. DI miscalculated the wall's weight-bearing capacity, leading to damage. A&K may argue that Due South breached their duty under the BMSMA by not ensuring the building was fit for habitation and occupation. However, the six-year limitation period may be a barrier to their claim, as the house was built more than 80 years ago.

**Conclusion**: While A&K may have a potential claim against Due South for the defective wall, the limitation period under the BMSMA may prevent them from pursuing this claim successfully. They should seek legal advice to determine the viability of their claim.
